subject: Design
subcategory: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us
title: The Mars Climate Orbiter: Metric vs. Imperial
description: One-minute skill: The Mars Climate Orbiter: Metric vs. Imperial.

hook.text: In 1999, NASA lost a $125 million spacecraft because one team used metric and another used imperial. Oops.

buildup.text: The Mars Climate Orbiter was designed to study Mars's atmosphere. Lockheed Martin built its software.

discovery.text: Lockheed's code outputted force in pound-seconds. NASA's code expected newton-seconds. Nobody caught the mismatch.

twist.text: The orbiter entered Mars's atmosphere at the wrong angle and burned up. A unit conversion error destroyed years of work.

climax.text: The disaster showed that interface design between systems matters as much as the systems themselves.

punchline.text: $125 million lost because nobody checked the units. Design details matter.

quiz.question: What caused the loss of the Mars Climate Orbiter?
options: One team used metric while another used imperial units
